public class Utils

isInInterval

public static boolean isInInterval(java.math.BigInteger arg,
                                   int powerLower,
                                   int powerUpper)
Tests if a BigInteger value lies in a given range, indicated by binary exponents, i.e., arg in [ 2^powerLower..2^powerUpper].

Parameters:
arg - BigInteger to have its bound checked.
powerLower - Bit length for inclusive lower bound.
powerUpper - Bit length for inclusive upper bound.
Returns:
True if arg is within specified range, i.e., 2^powerLower <= arg <= 2^powerUpper.

Parameters:
arg - Argument to be tested.
bitLength - Bit length of the interval.
Returns:
True if -2^bitlength + 1 <= arg <= 2^biglength - 1.

randomOddBigNumber

public static java.math.BigInteger randomOddBigNumber(int bitLength,
                                                      java.security.SecureRandom theRandom)
Generates a random number of bitLength bit length. The first two bits and the last bit of this number are always set, therefore the number is odd and >= (2^(bitLength-1)+2^(bitLength-2)+1).

Parameters:
bitLength - Length of the number to be generated, in bits.
theRandom - Secure random number generator.
Returns:
A random number of bitLength bit length with first and last bits set.

genPrime

                                            int primeCertainty)
Generates a number that is a regular prime number with a given probability and that is of the given bit length.

Parameters:
bitLength - Bit length of the generated number.
primeCertainty - Certainty of the number being a prime.
Returns:
Probable prime (with indicated certainty) of the given length.

computeSafePrime

public static java.math.BigInteger computeSafePrime(int bitlength,
                                                    int primeCertainty)
The main method to compute a random safe prime of the specified bit length. IMPORTANT: The computed prime will have two first bits and the last bit set to 1! That is, the prime is greater than (2^(bitlength-1)+2^(bitlength-2)+1). This is done to be sure that if two primes of bit length n are multiplied, the result will have the bitLength of 2*n exactly. TODO (bus) check if we can still keep the following comment for Open Source: This implementation uses the algorithm proposed by Ronald Cramer and Victor Shoup in "Signature Schemes Based on the strong RSA Assumption" May 9, 2000.

Parameters:
bitlength - the bit length of the safe prime to be computed.
primeCertainty - the probability that the computed number is not prime is (2^(-primeCertainty)).
Returns:
a number which is considered to be a safe prime with the prime certainty as specified.

computeGenerator

public static java.math.BigInteger computeGenerator(java.math.BigInteger modulus,

                                                    SystemParameters sp)

Compute a generator of the group of quadratic residue modulo n. The generator will not be part of the subgroup of size 2.

Parameters:
n - the modulus.
sp - System parameters.
Returns:
group generator of group of quadratic residues modulo n.

modPow

public static java.math.BigInteger modPow(java.math.BigInteger base,
                                          java.math.BigInteger exponent,
                                          java.math.BigInteger modulus)
Calculates the modular exponentiation with base^exponent (mod modulus) and returns the result.

Parameters:
base - Base of the exponentiation.
exponent - Exponent.
modulus - Modulus.
Returns:
base^exponent (mod modulus).

expMul

public static java.math.BigInteger expMul(java.math.BigInteger product,
                                          java.math.BigInteger base,
                                          java.math.BigInteger exponent,
                                          java.math.BigInteger modulus)
Expose and multiply modulo modulus operation. This is the heart of the Idemix algorithms and thus we have this convenience method. It also is the place to start optimizations.

Parameters:
product - Product that will be multiplied with the product of the exponentiation. MAY be null.
base - Base of the exponentiation.
exponent - Exponent.
modulus - Modulus.
Returns:
product * base^exponent (mod modulus).

extendedEuclid

public static java.math.BigInteger[] extendedEuclid(java.math.BigInteger a,
                                                    java.math.BigInteger b)
Computes s and t such that a*s + b*t = gcd(a, b). Using the extended Euclid algorithm as described in "A Computational Introduction to Number Theory and Algebra" by Victor Shoup the values of s and t are computed and returned as an array.

Parameters:
a - first argument of the gcd method.
b - second argument of the gcd method.
Returns:
array [s,t] such that s*a + t*b = gcd(a,b).

computeFSChallenge

public static final java.math.BigInteger computeFSChallenge(SystemParameters sp,
                                                            java.math.BigInteger context,
                                                            java.math.BigInteger capU,
                                                            java.util.Vector<AttributeStructure> attStructs,
                                                            Values theValues,
                                                            java.math.BigInteger nym,
                                                            java.math.BigInteger domNym,
                                                            java.math.BigInteger capUTilde,
                                                            java.util.HashMap<java.lang.String,java.math.BigInteger> capCTilde,
                                                            java.math.BigInteger nymTilde,
                                                            java.math.BigInteger domNymTilde,
                                                            java.math.BigInteger n1)
This method computes the Fiat-Shamir challenges for both the Recipient and the Issuer. Note that the values must be set properly: distinction between tilde-values and hat-Values for Recipient vs. Issuer. But since the FS challenge is rather symmetrical, it made sense to have one method to assemble the data and compute the hash.

Parameters:
sp - System parameters (used to retrieve the bit length of the hash).
context - Context (hashed for security reasons).
capU - Common value of the CL proof.
attStructs - Attribute structures (used for the committed attributes).
theValues - Values (used to retrieve the commitments).
nym - Pseudonym (may be null).
domNym - Domain pseudonym (may be null).
capUTilde - T-value of the proof.
capCTilde - Additional commitments (needed for the committed attributes).
nymTilde - Additional commitment.
domNymTilde - Additional commitment.
n1 - Nonce.
Returns:
Fiat-Shamir hash value.

computeChallenge

public static java.math.BigInteger computeChallenge(SystemParameters sp,
                                                    java.math.BigInteger context,
                                                    java.util.Vector<java.math.BigInteger> bigIntList,
                                                    java.math.BigInteger n1,
                                                    java.util.Collection<MessageToSign> messages)
Computes the Fiat-Shamir challenge. Note: this method is also used in the verification.

Parameters:
sp - System parameters.
context - Context for the proof.
bigIntList - List of values that will be included into the hash.
n1 - Nonce to make the proof.
messages - Messages.
Returns:
Value of Fiat-Shamir challenge.

public static final java.math.BigInteger computeContext(IssuerPublicKey pk)
Compute the context. This is a hash over all the public parameters and the issuer public key.

Returns:
Context for the proof.

computeCommitment

public static java.math.BigInteger computeCommitment(GroupParameters gp,
                                                     java.math.BigInteger m,
                                                     java.math.BigInteger r)
Computes a multi-base exponentiation with the bases as specified in the group parameters. For example, this is used to compute the value of a pseudonym.

Parameters:
gp - Group parameters.
m - Message value.
r - Randomness.
Returns:
g^m * h^r (mod capGamma).

                                                   java.math.BigInteger c,
                                                   java.math.BigInteger v)
Computes vTilde + c*v.

Parameters:
vTilde - Random value.
c - Challenge
v - Original value.
Returns:
vTilde + c*v.

getTildeRandom

Choose a random number of length lm + lPhi + lH. SystemParameter class provides definition of these lengths.

Returns:
Random value.
